Description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration imposed a $70 million cash penalty against Takata in connection with defective air bag inflators and said that another $130 million would be payable if the company did not live up to its commitment to phase out the faulty inflators or if it committed other safety violations.

Tokyo-based Takata Corporation agreed to plead guilty to wire fraud and pay a total of $1 billion in criminal penalties stemming from the company's fraudulent conduct in relation to sales of defective airbag inflators.

TK Holdings, Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of Takata, agreed to pay a civil penalty of $650 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation alleging that it concealed highly dangerous defects in its airbag inflators.

Takata Corp. agreed to pay $7 million to Hawaii, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and the State of New Mexico in settlement of allegations it knowingly sold airbags containing a chemical propellant that could degrade in a dangerous fashion. This settlement was separate from a larger multistate lawsuit.
Agency: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
